HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE

  • The term Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) includes propane, butane and mixtures of the two

  • The LPG at the PP(M)SB facility, and in Malaysia generally, is approximately 60% butane and 40% propane

  • LPG is a gas at ambient temperature and pressure, but is readily liquefied by either pressure and/or refrigeration

  • At PP(M)SB, LPG is stored as a liquid under pressure at ambient temperature

  • The vapour pressure is approximately 5 barg at 30Â°C

  • The density of liquid LPG is approximately 536 kg/m3 under saturated conditions

  • Leaks of liquid LPG result in the formation of large clouds of vapour

  • Since the volume of vapour at atmospheric pressure is approximately 250 times the volume of liquid, even small quantities of LPG vapour in air may form a flammable mixture

  • The limits of flammability of LPG are determined by the proportions of propane and butane in the mixture

  • However, approximate flammability limits are 2% to 9% by volume of gas in air; stoichiometric proportions are achieved with a 3.5% gas in air mixture

  • LPG vapour is heavier than air, and therefore tends to form a cloud along the ground or collect in drains

  • Pure LPG is an odourless material. However, Ethyl Mercaptan odorant is added to enable LPG leaks to be detected by smell

  • LPG vapour is transparent, but clouds usually appear as a white mist due to water vapour condensed in the air

  • LPG has a low viscosity, hence it has no lubricating properties and it is more likely to find a leakage path than water or most other petroleum products

  • These facts are significant with respect to the design of plant and have particular relevance to the glands and seals of pumps, compressors and valves

  • The cooling which occurs on evaporation of liquid LPG causes frost burns to the skin and damage to eyes if protection (gloves and goggles) is not available, and may cause ice formation on exposed equipment

  • LPG whether in liquid or vapour form, is only slightly toxic

  • The vapour is an asphyxiate and an anaesthetic, but only in high concentrations

  • Liquid LPG has a high coefficient of expansion.

  • Therefore LPG equipment must be provided with adequate ullage and or relief valves to prevent it becoming over-pressured as a result of temperature increases (e.g. due to heating in the sun)
